On Friday, April 5, 2013, stephanenicolas wrote:

This pull request is about injecting stuff in views in the same way as we
do in activities and fragments.
I know this has been asked a lot and up to now, roboguice didn't support
it directly. It was possible, mainly by calling manually
Roboguice.injectMembers as mentioned herehttps://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!topic/roboguice/65U3m8ykT18
.
Nevertheless, this technique could be improved and the same result could
be achieved automatically in the following case :
- custom view is used inside an XML Layout, not programmatically.
- custom view inside a RoboActivity
In that case, which is the most common one, this pull request will inject
everything annotated via Roboguice inside the custom view.
The main idea is to use the fact that activities are also view factories
when XML inflation is used.
N.B : 1 I couldn't write a robolectric test using a xml layout inside
roboguice tests.
N.B : 2 code has only been tested manually within astroboy
Sorry to have messed up configuration files (so don't take them), but I
had to do it to achieve a proper eclipse configuration using maven android
plugin.

On Tuesday, April 30, 2013, Charles Munger wrote:


I haven't written any tests for new functionality, so don't merge
   yet.
I would like to make some breaking changes to the API, but I'd like
   to gather feedback first. Specifically, I'd like to move all classes that
   depend on the support package to roboguice.fragments.support, and all
   packages that depend on native fragments to
   roboguice.fragments.provided. I'd then deprecate all the classes in
   roboguice.fragments.*, and replace them with empty classes that extend
   the moved support-based classes. For example, the current RoboFragmentwould be replaced with:

package roboguice.fragments;@Deprecatedpublic class RoboFragment extends roboguice.fragments.support.RoboFragment {}
Someone with more Maven skills than I could later make the support library
fragment classes a seperate POM, so people wishing to use Roboguice don't
have to mess with optional dependencies.
Also, I'd love any feedback on how to improve my code. It's a fairly major
change, and I replaced a lot of hackery with stuff that's a bit more type
safe, but when doing dynamic classloading and casting there's always a
potential for dragons.
Fixes #20 https://github.com/roboguice/roboguice/issues/20

I agree, that it isn't affecting our app negatively. (Though a warning is
always a small distraction.)
For our unit tests, which use RoboGuice (a custom 2.0) and Robolectric (a
custom 1.5), we have a leak which seems to be around Finalizers. We used
YourKit to do a memory profile of a test run. A snapshot after the tests
had reached a critical memory situation showed 730 instances of
com.google.inject.internal.InjectorImpl with a retained size of 108MB.
There are also 83,851 java.lang.ref.Finalizer instances. Given those
numbers I started looking for a known memory leak around Guice, and found
the above ticket.
Admittedly, it could be because of the old versions of our test tools, or
some other issue. If you really think this is the wrong tree, I will bark
somewhere else.

. This was postponed, see https://github.com/roboguice/roboguice/issues/174
. My idea was to use meta-data, but it looks like meta-data can't be applied to an application, only individual activities:

http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/meta-data-element.html
. Although this page seems to contradict: http://blog.iangclifton.com/2010/10/08/using-meta-data-in-an-androidmanifest/

bind(EventManager.class).annotatedWith(Names.named(GLOBAL_EVENT_MANAGER_NAME)).to(EventManager.class).asEagerSingleton();

Hm, you're right about the hierarchy filter, that may explain why i'm
seeing problems with the groupon app.  It would be nice to not have to scan
the entire hierarchy since we should be able to compute the topmost class
that has annotations during annotations processing.  It would also be nice
to not have to scan intermediate classes that don't have annotations.
I'm definitely open to fixing the AnnotationDatabase class, it was more a
proof of concept than real production code.
Naming convention wasn't clear.  In the following example:
class Foo {
     @Inject Bar bar;
}
getClasses will return Foo, and getInjectedClasses will return Bar.  Names
need to be made more clear.  getClasses is the list of classes that require
inspection for injection points, while getInjectedClasses is the list of
classes that have bindings.
AndroidManifest makes sense.
. The filtering out of intermediate classes is pretty valuable, because it
avoids having to scan every field, method, and constructor of that
intermediate class.
I think there's two things that we're doing essentially.  The first is
checking whether we have to proceed higher up in the hierarchy to scan for
additional injection points.  The second thing is checking whether we have
to scan the class at our current location in the hierarchy.  This second
thing is the list of classesContainingInjectionPoints in our annotation
database.  I'm not sure how to compute the first thing...

On Mar 22, 2014 6:18 PM, "lbrasseur" notifications@github.com wrote:
Scenario:
- A library project with package com.library.package
- An app project referencing the library with package com.app.package.
If you inject a resource like this:
@InjectResource(name="com.library.package:string/mytext")
private String myText;
it will not work, since Resources.getIdentifier() returns 0 if the
specified package is the library package.
However, the following binding works ok:
@InjectResource(name="com.app.package:string/mytext")
private String myText;
but referencing app package from library code creates unnecessary coupling.
This could be avoided by changing ResourceListener. getId() method could
be changed from:
protected int getId(Resources resources, InjectResource annotation) {
    int id = annotation.value();
    return id>=0 ? id : resources.getIdentifier(annotation.name(),null,null);
}
to
protected int getId(Resources resources, InjectResource annotation) {
    int id = annotation.value();
    return id>=0 ? id : resources.getIdentifier(annotation.name(),null,application.getPackageName());
}
This way, annotating the resource as:
@InjectResource(name="string/mytext")
private String myText;
will work ok, since app package is set as default.

generate Apps with a different package name in the Android manifest (as
explained here http://www.piwai.info/renaming-android-manifest-package/).
This is can be used to create two different app versions with the same code
base.

. Such a feature is actually present in the 2 main event frameworks I know about :)
- Otto with the Producers. Explained briefly here : http://stackoverflow.com/a/13293973/693752
- And event bus with sticky events.
I am not sure I am very happy with the actual implementation I submitted (actually I don't remember its details), but I think RoboGuice should really have a feature like this. 
Let's take a fragment, if you add to your activity, then if the activity fires an event, the fragment will get it.
BUT, if you do it the otherway around : first firing an event and then add the fragment, then the fragment will have lost that event. This will lead to code deduplication : 1) code to listen to the event and 2) code to set the fragment "manually" in a given state, no related to events. They will do the same stuff, but in a very different way, and with fragments it will lead to a huge amount of complexity to save their state in the arguments.
With producers/sticky events, the fragment could have received the event, even if it was added after the event was fired.
Producers offer a way to get an event lifecycle more independent from the Observer and Observable life cycles.
Oh, and last but not least : this pull request and feature enhancement has been motivated by a strong experience using RoboGuice  with fragments. In my most recent project we made a quite big app (for a bank, over 50 000 lines of code, 1000 classes) and it used a lot of fragments, and events to communicate with activities...
I will not insist and I trust your experience but I would love to be convinced by arguments stronger than mine. ;)

. @emmby 

I achieved the following and would like to confirm that it's OK with you : 
- we can generate the javadocs and upload them via (in root folder) : mvn site -pl roboguice
- the javadocs will be accessible on the github pages site - btw this page works.
As you can see the docs will be generated per version, including snapshots. I am not sure yet how things will go when releasing. I believe that a mvn release:perform command would not generate the site and publish it, so we would have to checkout the "prepare release" commit, publish the docs and move back to the HEAD.
Also, it would be nice if we changed the page http://roboguice.github.io/roboguice/ to list all versions of docs available. But this has to be changed manually after deploying a new version of the docs. Using this option, we could provide a link to the latest docs, but it has to be done manually, and we could keep the docs of previous versions online. I can't find a way to automate this. This can be documented for contributors and be included in some "Release procedure" document.
The alternative, to avoid any manual work, is to always publish on the same url : http://roboguice.github.io/roboguice/site/latest/roboguice/apidocs/index.html -this page doesn't exist yet- but we would then only have the latest version of the docs, and wouldn't keep any archive of the old versions. Each new version would just erase the previous one. This can be fully automated.
WDYT ?
Personally, I would go for the "latest" docs online only. The system is simpler, fully automated and we can release the javadocs + sources on maven in our release cycle already, for each version.

Btw, the system I suggest relies on the github pages, that is to say, everything is commited on the special gh-pages branch of the repo. We then have full control on it (beware not to checkout that branch in the same folder where source is checked out, it usually messes everything, prefer a new folder to clone the repo and checkout the gh-pages branch).

. @emmby  Oooppss, we got a problem.
There are some cases where our filtering mechanism can discard classes that should be processed for injection points, here is a counter-example : 
Let's focus on the @Inject annotation, and say we got 
java
public class MyRoboActivity extends RoboActivity {
//no injection at all
//or, even more specific : no @Inject annotation used 
//(but others, like @InjectView, can be used)
}
This means that MyRoboActivity will not be listed as "having an @Inject annotated field" by the annotation processor. But RoboActivity is actually marked as "having an @Inject annotated field". The filter would like to discard MyRoboActivity, but it should not as it should apply all injections that have been defined in its super class.
Workarounds : 
- we can, when filtering a class A, also consider its super classes. If a super class is marked as "having an @Inject annotated field", then A should be filtered in. This slows down the filtering process, an average of 20 ms on my side.
- we could add a new annotation : @InjeritsInjection or slightly modify @Inject (from Guice) and allow a class to be annotated with this annotation. If so, the preprocessor will have to put it in the same categories as its super classes : as "having an @Inject annotated field". That's much faster at runtime (we save the 20 ms added above), but it means that this annotation should not be forgotten, checking if it is forgotten is the same algorithm than in first bullet point, moreover it means we would slightly drift away from JSR 330 specs.
What do you prefer ? Any other idea ?
I would personally favor the first option has it is more robust and complies with existing code and standards.
. I opted for the first solution in the problem above.
I committed a few more changes : 
- the annotation processor now keeps track of everything thing to limit scanning of classes : constructors, methods, and fields that are injection points
- only those members are looped through when building injection points in Guice and RoboGuice
- the annotation processor now uses apache velocity template which is far more easy to use than JavaWriter in our case.
With the latests commits in both my Guice fork and my RoboGuice branch, I got performances as good as 225 ms to startup a RoboGuice app. Memory consumption is far lower as well and garbage collected is not running as much as before. Performance improvements are close to 75%.
I discovered a few things to do to get a better benchmarking (with less variation) : 
- don't allow background processes in device developer option (near bottom)
- use SystemClock.currentThreadTimeMillis() instead of System.currentTimemillis() 
- disable animations in device developer option (3 times).
With this all I get much more constant benchmark. They average 185 ms to startup the app, +/- 15 ms variation. BTW, these times are on Dalvik, and, as reflection is now quite restricted, on ART it gives around 400 ms, our best time as well.

I updated everything so that you can start reviewing the code. I am still hacking both Guice and RoboGuice and go something more and more advanced and stable now.
I could backport most of the annotation database system (for module binding filtering and type listening filtering for both fields, constructors, and methods) directly into Guice's core. I almost finished and I am going to push it soon. 
The idea is to have a complete solution to propose to Guice team.
A few things that have changed : 
- The annotation processor of Guice is called Blender, in RoboGuice : RoboBlender.
- annotation processing is now very subtitle to note classes that are injectable, map each annotation to the set of classes that use them, and why they use it : for a field, a constructor, a method, and which one.
- filtering is based on the above information
- binding filtering is also based on the above information
- Guice can be passed a few package names to lookup for annotation databases
- roboguice uses a metadata to know which package names to lookup for annotation databases
- the annotation processor can now be passed an argument when generating an annotation database to put it in a given package (replace the @AnnotationDatabasePackage mechanism that I didn't like)
- everything performs at full speed
There are 2 design questions that I need to solve : 
- the annotation processor in Guice is good for RoboGuice but too complex for Guice itself, I have to figure out how to have a simple annotation processor in Guice and extend it in RoboGuice
- the annotation based filter actually creates code deduplication, I am thinking of considering it as a decorator for a default filter, but still need to think about it.

. The problem is that you are defining a binding with an interface that contains some code that doesn't exist on a given platform. If android can deal with it when using the class directly, guice needs to create a binding representation of the interface and, for this it will load the interface into memory and will fail with the annotation that doesn't exist.
The same would happen if your interface contained reference to types that don't exist prior to a given SDK level. 
This issue is quite interesting from a guice development point of view. It shows some limitations on Android.
A workaround would be to have 2 interfaces : 
- one without the annotation
- one with the annotation extending the first one.
then, 
- in your module, use the right interface according to SDK level to create a binding. 
- in your code, use the second one. 
I think that should trick guice and still keep android happy.
. In this case, if you go to : 
http://www.findjar.com/index.x?query=Nullable+limit%3Anone
You see that findbugs defines this annotation (ok, you have to know you want the findbugs one, I agree).
So add the dependency to findbugs. Search it on central : 
http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cgav%7C1%7Cg%3A%22findbugs%22%20AND%20a%3A%22annotations%22
Add it to your project 
groovy
compile 'findbugs:annotations:1.0.0'
And annotate your field with it : 
java
@InjectFragment(R.id.fragmentContainer) 
@Nullable
private CrimeFragment fragment;
Your IDE should resolve the import.
. Please note that there is also an annotation in android.support.annotation.Nullable, it's much simpler :)
. Both @InjectView and @InjectFragment work in the same way : if the thing
injected is null, then the field has to be annotated with @Nullable
otherwise, an exception is thrown.
Now the question may be : why is my fragment null during onCreate ?
Do you add the fragment via XML ? Do you create it by hand ? Are you sure
the fragment should be there during onCreate of the activity ?

after injection for the first time onCreate is called.

. In RoboGuice, by default everything that is injected has to be non null after injection.

The error you get means that after XML inflation, your view is null. This can happen under 2 circumstances : 
- this view is not referenced in your XML layout and you made a mistake
- this view is not referenced in ALL XML layout configurations, for instance it can be present in landscape and not in portrait. 
In the second case, you would like to add a @Nullable annotation to this field. The Nullable annotation can come from any class/package you want (there are so many libs providing this annotation..). The only constraint is that the annotation has to be named Nullable.
A field annotated with the Nullable annotation can be null after injection without creating any error.
Please note that we kept this question in issues as a FAQ for other devs, but usually, you should have used the discussion group to ask a question, not GH issue pages.

2014-11-07 15:58 GMT-05:00 falc0r notifications@github.com:

I've run into a few issues with constructor injection when disabling
annotation databases. Member injection runs through the
InjectionPoint.getInjectionPoints methods, which resets the
RoboGuiceHierarchyTraversalFilter on each call. Constructor injection runs
through the InjectionPoint.forConstructorOf method which doesn't reset the
filter but instead uses it's previous state. When I have classes that
require construction injection I find that the
RoboGuiceHierarchyTraversalFilter thinks that it is in a RoboGuice package
and determines that it isn't worth scanning for injectable constructors,
resulting in an erroneous "Could not find a suitable constructor" type
Guice configuration error. I've found that switching to member injection is
a potential workaround, but I'd prefer to use immutable classes where
possible.
Here's a link
https://www.dropbox.com/s/jnnv38g8p8d4285/RG3Test_bug.zip?dl=0 to a
simple (~5 class) project that breaks when the Injector is created.
And here's another
https://www.dropbox.com/s/jnnv38g8p8d4285/RG3Test_bug.zip?dl=0 slightly
modified version of the above that shows it working with member injection.
—

. Hi @hob90 ,
let's start with the module question. You can still define RG modules but the only 2 things that changed are : 
- module constructors should now have an application parameter (it used to be a context)
- modules are declared in the AndroidManifest metadata, not into a separate xml as with RG 2
But I think you got all that already as you read the migration guide.
About the first problem you have, that is really strange. It looks like your activity class is not embedded into the apk. 
Can you please confirm that you don't use multidex ?
Also, can you dexdump the apk and grep class descriptors to see if the activity class is there ?
And please, double or triple check your AndroidManifest and the activity name.
Also, there might be something wrong in classloading prior to this error. Clear you logcat ,relaunch the app and check all log levels, especially warnings. Dalvik reports unloadable classes at this level (as it may not be an error but a lazily loaded class that should not be loaded due to fragmentation).
And, use mvn -X to get sure to see all bad things that can happen during the build.
Finally, did you try disabling RoboBlender to see if the error is related to it ?
And I wanna see your pom too ;)

. The problem is not solved because we don't think there is any problem. 
The main thing with this issue is that for now, we didn't receive enough information from people using eclipse. We currently don't use eclipse as most of the Android community migrated to Android Studio. We don't support ant neither as most of the community moved to Gradle. If people want to use eclipse/ant, it would be nice if they could report the problem here correctly, with details and answering all the questions we ask.
Maybe for all developers that don't fully master their build processes, we should recommend to disable RoboBlender optimizations as it requires some knowledge of how your IDE and build system works. Please refer to the RoboBlender wiki to see how to disable RoboBlender.
. Can you :
- clear logcat
- launch the app
- check warning logs, (orange color in Android Studio) and report any
  problem with loaded classes issued by Dalvik.
Also, please note that we strongly consider now that minimum sdk for most
devices is level 10, not sure we will put a lot of efforts in supporting
lower android sdks.

. Hi @victoriazheng ,


a few things : 
I strongly advise you don't use '+' in your dependencies on Gradle. This looks like a nice feature, but as an app developer you should always be in full control of your dependencies. We do our best to test our release and I guess all libs do, but it would be very bad if, without modifying your code you get a new bug because a dependency introduced it.
Did you read our RoboBlender wiki ? It may be a bit long, but I got the feeling that it would solve the problem you have.
Here are a few things we need to fix your bug : 
- is com.some.CustomModule a java class ? It may sound a bit silly as a question, but it's not clear to me what you call a "module file". Except that, all seems fine for the setup. 
- I guess your app doesn't use any lib that uses Guice / RoboGuice, otherwise you should mention a package to generate the annotation database into (see RoboBlender wiki).
- how do you use your SharedPreferencesHelper class ? I mean do you somewhere use @Inject SharedPreferencesHelper helper or you just inject it manually without annotations (using RoboGuice.getInjector(..).getInstance(...)) only? In the latter case, you need to tell so to RoboBlender (see wiki) and you will have to superBind the class in your custom module.
I am pretty sure you are close to get RG 3 working.

. I agree that the wiki could be more clear for people not so familiar with Events in RG. 

To use the global event manager, which means you want to communicate from a context to a different context, simply use : 
java
//get the global event manager
@Named(DefaultRoboModule.GLOBAL_EVENT_MANAGER_NAME) 
@Inject EventManager globalEventManager;
....
//somewhere in code
globalEventManager.fire(new MyAPIEvent());
Do not register it in your module, this is already done in DefaultRoboModule. 
To receive the events, 
``` java
//get the global event manager
@Named(DefaultRoboModule.GLOBAL_EVENT_MANAGER_NAME) 
@Inject EventManager globalEventManager;
//define a listener 
EventListener listener = new EventListener() {
            @Override
            public void onEvent(UpdateEvent e) {
        }
    };

//you should register a listener
globalEventManager.registerObserver(eventClass, listener );
```
You will have to manage the registration and unregistration of the listener, RG doesn't handle it when you want to use a specific event manager. RG manages automatically registration and unregistration  for an event manager local to an activity, a service, etc. See wiki for more details.
If you find a way to improve the wiki, we would be happy about that.
. Hi guys,
RoboGuice will stop providing all exotic varieties and activities and
fragments with RG 4.
We plan a lot of changes, making RG more focused and efficient, small, we
will drop a few non necessary features, and among them the support for
every single activity type. The reason for that is that Android becoming
more advanced, and the Android community with it, we don't feel that
repeating the same code in different classes adds a lot of value to RG. We
think it provides value to non advanced devs by making it easy to bootstrap
an activity, but inheritance is a hard constraint and leads us to a lot of
code duplication in RG.
Please, add the class in the PR to your project, this will be the new way
to do things a la RG soon.

. Hi Sunil,

I would advise 2 things:
1) your problem sounds like a proguard problem. If you use proguard in
release and not in debug, you should check that the database has not been
obfuscated by proguard.
2) you should consider customizing the package of the annotation database
generated by RoboGuice/RoboBlender, there are some parameters you can pass
to the annotation processor during the build to generate the annotation
database in a given package. Using the default package is really only for
toy apps.

. You don't have to create an additional intermediate collection for addAll. That's all the point of this class : not adding data structures that will be garbage collected as soon as the database merge will have happened.
. There are indeed mulitple issues that led me to use a map of map : 
- a proper custom data structure would be the best here, something that gives the operations needed in fastest time. But to do this, as we need both the data structure in the RoboGuice runtime and RoboBlender (the annotation processor), this means that, to avoid a cycle in maven modules, we would need to introduce a new module (like Blender-lib) to the RoboGuice o Guice project, and I didn't dare doing it.
- so I fell back on using language-provided data structures, hence this map of maps
- hashmaps are supposed to provide lookup in 0(1) average, O(n) worst case with pathological data (that we don't have). A map of map is thus in O(1) average too.
- to circumvent the low meaning-ness of a map of map, compared to having proper structure carrying it, I used quite verbose variable names for those maps. That's the best I could find.
I tried to save on every possible CPU cycle, if a data structure was not needed, I didn't create it to help the garbage collector running less frequently and consuming less user sensitive time. A map of map seemed like a "raw/low-level/fast" data structure that could be justified in that specific case.

. The annotation compiler parameter is now optional. The whole lib uses the default package by default. And this can still be customized. 
So, to use Dagger, according to this page, you need : 
xml
  <dependency>
    <groupId>com.squareup.dagger</groupId>
    <artifactId>dagger-compiler</artifactId>
    <version>${dagger.version}</version>
    <optional>true</optional>
  </dependency>
<dependencies>
  <dependency>
    <groupId>com.squareup.dagger</groupId>
    <artifactId>dagger</artifactId>
    <version>${dagger.version}</version>
  </dependency>
</dependencies>
and to use our stuff, you need : 
xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.roboguice</groupId>
    <artifactId>roboblender</artifactId>
    <version>${roboguice.version}</version>
    <scope>provided</scope>
</dependency>
<dependency>
    <groupid>org.roboguice</groupid>
    <artifactid>roboguice</artifactid>
    <version>${roboguice.version}</version>
</dependency>
I can't see the difference.BTW, provided and optional have the same effect on scope.

. Your Activity needs to inherit from RoboFragmentActivity. Then you can display the dialog with
fragment.show( getSupportFragmentManager() , "tag");
(you have to use the support fragment manager instead of the normal fragment manager)
You can use either onCreateDialog() or onCreateView(). It depends on what you want to do. Display a complex view? Display an alert dialog? You can read about it here.
. onViewCreated will only called if you use a custom view. You can use either a custom view or a pre-built Android Dialog (onCreateDialog). Not both at once.
By the way: this is Android specific and has nothing to do with Roboguice :wink:
. onViewCreated() will not be called because you are not overriding onCreateView(). See my answer here and here.

. Dependency injection makes moving between support fragments and native fragments easy - my code allows changing between them with nothing but a change in import statements. This change  allows devs to use the support classes, and when fragments have widespread enough adoption they can switch to native easily. It also lets devs use native now, and switch to using support easily when new APIs are added. 

It's not like native fragments are deprecated. 
.

davcamer:
Any vague timeline for the Guice 4.0 upgrade? "Whenever Milestone 3 is ready?"
. I just know they are on 4.0-alpha.
I'm looking for a fix to this finalizer issue: https://code.google.com/p/google-guice/issues/detail?id=786
This is hammering us significantly on our unit tests. It could be we are doing something wrong in our unit tests, but I haven't figured it out, if we are.
. I agree, that it isn't affecting our app negatively. (Though a warning is always a small distraction.)
For our unit tests, which use RoboGuice (a custom 2.0) and Robolectric (a custom 1.5), we have a leak which seems to be around Finalizers. We used YourKit to do a memory profile of a test run. A snapshot after the tests had reached a critical memory situation showed 730 instances of com.google.inject.internal.InjectorImpl with a retained size of 108MB. There are also 83,851 java.lang.ref.Finalizer instances. Given those numbers I started looking for a known memory leak around Guice, and found the above ticket.
Admittedly, it could be because of the old versions of our test tools, or some other issue. If you really think this is the wrong tree, I will bark somewhere else.
. We are trying RoboGuice 2.0 with Guice 4.0beta using some  in our pom.xml. We are still experiencing memory leaks, that I believe could be caused by the anonymous inner class thread local in Guice's InjectorImpl. I see that is changed in the latest code to a static inner class: https://code.google.com/p/google-guice/source/browse/core/src/com/google/inject/internal/InjectorImpl.java#1064
Anyway, upgrading to 4.0 would close this ticket. I'll follow up with explanation if we get to the bottom of the memory leaks we are seeing. 
. Since it is a test thing, putting it on RoboGuice.util along with reset() would make a lot of sense. I'm not sure if we could take the same approach of adding to the injectors map lazily.
.
goldierox:
The MapFragment and SupportMapFragment are part of Google Play Services. As far as I know, there's no way to include these in RoboGuice without requiring devs to include Google Play Services too. If someone wants injection for these fragments, it should be straight forward to copy the source and add it themselves.
.

kelsos:
I also encountered the same issue at some point while working with RoboGuice 2.0 so my guess is that it is not restricted to ActionBarActivity.
. The provided namespace is for use with the native fragments supported in the latest versions of Android.  If you want the support RoboFragment for older versions check a level above (remove the provided from the namespace). 
You need to import roboguice.fragment.RoboFragment instead of roboguice.fragment.provided.RoboFragment 
. I am really not sure how this blocks any kind of sdk updates, since you can easily work around the issue inside your project.
Here is the source of AppCompatActivity.
You can create your own RoboAppCompatActivity as a base for your activities by copying the code of the original AppCompatActivity and then making it inherit from RoboFragmentActivity or some other basic RoboActivity.
. Usually I create my modules like the following example:
``` java
package com.sample.roboguice
import com.google.inject.AbstractModule;
public class Module extends AbstractModule{
  @Override protected void configure() {
}
}
```
The configure method has all your bindings e.g.:
java
 bind(ObjectMapper.class).toProvider(ObjectMapperProvider.class).asEagerSingleton();
Does this help?
. Have you tried deactivating the Instant Run option in Android Studio?
. I had to rebuild roboblender with the following lines mentioned above and use a local snapshot.
. It has been a while since the v4.0.0 release. I have already upgraded two projects to v4.0.0 and it works without an issue.
There is no news on updated documentation yet as far as I know. 
Regarding the change log, it focuses mostly on performance optimizations and gets rid of all the Robo* classes, which in turn means that you have to do some extra work in order to get it running.
. @milind169 RoboGuice is not under development anymore.
You should consider either creating your own RoboAppCompatActivity based on the RoboActionBarActivity and include it in your project, or if you have the time and resources you should migrate to another DI framework that is actively maintained.
I found out that the migration path from RoboGuice to Toothpick was relatively easy. I am pretty sure there are also a couple of tutorials on how to migrate available on the web..

I'm not sure if this is the best issue for this, but the wiki documentation for registering custom modules is incorrect.
The example as shown is:

In your AndroidManifest.xml file, add some meta-data inside the application tag and list all the fully qualified class names of your modules

However, this does not actually work. The correct path, I discovered, is outlined on the old Google Code upgrade path page:

you may specify a custom module classname in a string-array resource called "roboguice_modules" in res/values/roboguice.xml

This library seems very promising, but when the (very basic!) setup steps are wrong it's discouraging, especially when it seems that a new major release is on the horizon. Is the problem simply lack of time/volunteers as the issue tag suggests? What's the best way to submit PRs for the docs here?

. Well, one such side effect is that you don't publish the Guice types in your -sources artifact, meaning I get no Javadocs on Guice types (which is helpful when working with more complex module bindings). The same appear to be true for the javax artifacts, though source/javadocs for those is less important.
. Discovered another side effect that is a dealbreaker; adding a Guice extension such as the Multibindings (com.google.inject.extensions:guice-multibindings:3.0) extension will fail at runtime for a NoClassDefFoundError for com.google.inject.internal.util.ImmutableList. Your repackaged version does not include this class from what I can see. I cannot include Guice 3.0 myself because of the aforementioned duplicate class entry warnings from Dex so it's not clear to me how one could use these extensions without having to repackage them themselves.
. Update -- managed to work around this after realizing Roboguice 3 was relying on Guice 4 fork, so multibindings 4.0-beta5 works (after excluding its transitive dependency).

zawadz88:
I had the same error, but only when using ProGuard for some reason. My configuration consisted of build tools 23.0.2, Android Gradle plugin 2.0.0-alpha3 and lots of included libraries so multidex was also enabled.
I was able to solve it by adding in the ProGuard config file:
-keep public class * extends com.google.inject.AnnotationDatabase
And in app's build.gradle:
project.tasks.withType(JavaCompile) { task ->
    options.compilerArgs << "-AguiceAnnotationDatabasePackageName=com.myapp.package"
}
And finally by adding in the AndroidManifest.xml under application tag:
<meta-data android:name="roboguice.annotations.packages" android:value="com.myapp.package"/>
I got the idea from: http://www.bhyuu.com/roboblender-use-annotation-databases-with-multiple-modules/
.

timroes:
I can confirm this bug. After half a day of disassembling and diffing files (with a correct build from JDK 1.7), it seems that some JDK version have a problem to correctly generate the AnnotationDatabaseImpl file. In the broken version the fillAnnotationClassesAndMethods() methods is completely empty (and some other stuff is missing too) which leads to events not working at all.
I updated my JDK form 1.8.0_05 to 1.8.0_45 and it started working. So for the case anyone is still stumble across this (as I did), update your JDK to the most recent versions and things seem to be fine.
.
jeromevdl:
Same problem than @timroes, same workaround. Just update JDK to 1.8.0_45 and it works !
.
falc0r:
No, I haven't put any more effort other than investigation into this yet.  My initial thoughts are to just add more filter resets in the other methods of InjectionPoint, but I haven't looked into the potential side effects of that yet.  My main concern is that member injection may loop back around to the constructor injection methods when provisioning dependencies and could then reset the filter when it shouldn't be, but that may not cause any problems.
. Hey Stephane, I don't have any problem with this being pushed back, as mentioned above I was able to create an annotation database that solved the problem.  I don't think the fix will be too difficult though so I'm playing with it now in my fork.
I didn't realize that type literals and assisted injection would introduce performance problems.  I'm using type literals now but my project isn't that large (so probably only about 10 - 20) and haven't noticed any issues.  It is something good to keep in mind going forward though.
. Created PR #269 
. @xtien, my fork for this project is RG 3.0 + the fix for this issue if you don't mind building my fork.  Alternatively, you can add this AnnotationDatabase to your project which is what I ended up doing (with proprietary stuff stripped from the linked file).  It contains the same information that would be added to an autogenerated AnnotationDatabase by my PR.

AlexKolpa:
Sorry for not being clear enough in the issue, I didn't research the problem thoroughly back then. The problem occurs in SharedPreferencesProvider#L59. What seems to go wrong is that new File("shared_prefs" + ROBOGUICE_1_DEFAULT_FILENAME) is actually looking for a new file relative to the root, meaning you get a file pointing to a /shared_prefs directory, instead of the desired /data/data/<package>/shared_prefs directory. This  directory is of course never readable, causing this to always fail.
. @stephanenicolas did you have a look at my explanation? If you want, I can also create a quick test to demonstrate that new File("shared_prefs" + ROBOGUICE_1_DEFAULT_FILENAME).canRead() always returns false.
.

1zaman:
Looks like the annotations from the support library, as well as the Jetbrains and Lombok ones, are only meant for compile-time checks and are not retained at runtime. All of them declare their retention policy as CLASS (the default), instead of RUNTIME. I guess we'll need to define our own custom retained Nullable annotation if we need to support conditional injections.

Your gradle build tells me ths you're using groovy - apply plugin: 'groovyx.grooid.groovy-android' - and that means the code is being compiled using "groovyc" and not "javac".  Compile time annotation processing is completely different between the two compilers so I'd expect that it would break injection at that point.

I managed to hack support for Multibinder back in by adding another annotation database, with the following contents:
https://gist.github.com/btilbrook-nextfaze/7f231c356fca2cac145d
So overall I needed to configure RoboGuice with the the following annotation processor packages:
- <my app package>
- Default package
- roboguice
Thanks go to @falc0r for their work on getting assisted injection to work, which is essentially the same problem as multibinding.
Related: https://github.com/roboguice/roboguice/issues/266

clementhely:
To solve it, we basically changed our activity to extend ActionBarActivity and to implement RoboContext, instead of simply extending RoboActionBarActivity. This means we had to replicate the lifecycle and injection logic from RoboActionBarActivity, removing the lines responsible for the crash.
Did that a while ago, so I'm not exactly sure what the logic behind it was, but after investigating, we figured that the crash was happening because of these lines, in the onCreateView() methods:
java
if (RoboActivity.shouldInjectOnCreateView(name))
            return RoboActivity.injectOnCreateView(name, context, attrs);
So creating our own activity class, without these two calls to RoboActivity.injectOnCreateView(name, context, attrs) solved the problem. I think this is because shouldInjectOnCreateView(String) was checking if the name contained a package name, and if the package name wasn't starting by com.android. But looking at this commit, it seems that this behaviour changed in Roboguice 3.0 (at the time we were using 3.0.0-alpha2), so it's possible that this issue is not happening anymore, otherwise you can create your own activity class, removing the calls to RoboActivity.injectOnCreateView, as we did.
.

GyulaJuhasz:
Hi!
I encountered the same issue multiple times. I consider this a bug, since the exception message is wrong or not set. There is a simple workaround: register an UncaughtExceptionHandler for your application. In the handler, check if the exception (or one of its causes) is a CreationError or ProvisionError, and if that is the case, log the error messages of the exception "manually" before propagating the exception.

pcockerell:
I haven't seen it for a while, with later 2.1 beta releases. I've just upgraded to AS 2.1 final, so if it doesn't recur within a week or so, I'll close this.

ohin:
The only way I've got this issue resolved (temporarily) is to downgrade the gradle build tools in main build.gradle file to 2.0.0:
classpath 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:2.0.0'
Still, the Instant Run needs to be disabled.
.
skydevht:
Same problem, same workaround. But it's a shame 'cause Instant run is so cool. I've flashed my phone to lollipop just for it...
.
liraz:
I suspect that Instant Run is checking changes statically, while RoboGuice is injecting through reflection - so the process of Instant Run thinks the injections are not really being used, so things are being omitted..
But that's just an assumption.
Version 2.1.2 is out, and the problem still persists - i can't use the huge benefits of Instant Run because i chose RoboGuice for my project. 
.
